comments.author: bclaise
comments.body:
It's time to update this document, as it mainly focuses on MIB developments
Example 1:

   Most of the existing IETF management standards are focused on using
   Structure of Management Information (SMI)-based data models (MIB
   modules) to monitor and manage networking devices. 

   ...

   For years the IETF community has used the IETF Standard Management
   Framework, including the Simple Network Management Protocol
   [[RFC3410](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3410)], the Structure of Management Information [[RFC2578](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2578)], and MIB
   data models for managing new protocols.

Example 2: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/statement-iesg-writable-mib-module-iesg-statement-20140302/ has been written 5 years after this document, and should be integrated in a new version.

comments.author: sbarguil
comments.body:
I believe it’s important to incorporate modern modeling practices and operational realities, especially with the increasing adoption of YANG. Below are some key areas I suggest we consider:

**Use of YANG Data Models**: Address how the use of standardized YANG models affects the manageability aspects defined in RFC 5706, including alignment with existing operational and configuration workflows.

**Impact of NMDA**: Clarify how the transition to the NMDA approach—where intended configuration, applied configuration, and operational state are clearly separated—impacts the way we define and assess manageability requirements.

**State and Operational Data**: Emphasize the need to define how both state and operational data should be exposed and validated within the scope of manageability, especially for troubleshooting and monitoring purposes.

**Reflection of Actual Network State**: Ensure that manageability definitions consider whether the data models accurately reflect the live state of the network, enabling better diagnostics and real-time visibility.

issues.title: Reword based on recent erratum
issues.author: xorrkaz
issues.body:
This paragraph was flagged (albeit incorrectly) for errata (Section 3.6.1):

"The protocol document should make clear the limitations implicit
within the protocol and the behavior when limits are exceeded.  This
should be considered in a data-modeling-independent manner -- what
makes managed-protocol sense, not what makes management-protocol-
sense."

If this is left in the final document, differentiating between the protocol or specification to be managed and the protocol doing the management should be clearer.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
I'm not sure this was used outside the IETF. 

The issue with the OLD title is that it is interpreted as specific to protocol work. For example, this may exclude BCPs where ops guidance would be key. 

As indicated in #14, this PR is for "discussion/further tweaking/etc." ;-)

comments.author: xorrkaz
comments.body: I understand your desire to broaden the scope outside of protocol work.  And I don't know if other SDOs or organizations referenced this previously.  My point was that it might further dissuade such groups from considering these guidelines.

reviews.author: xorrkaz
reviews.body: This can be bikeshedded to death, and I do like the proposed change.  It raised a question, though.  Yes, we are the IETF, and we can only "control" our own work.  But we do liaise with other groups where these guidelines might be useful.  The previous title didn't preclude them whereas this change _might_.
